title: Touching base on Runes Balance for Pre-season
body:
Hey, all. Maple Nectar here, Producer on the Live Team (aka Balance team).

IT’S HAPPENING!!! As you’ve almost certainly noticed, Runes Reforged is finally here! I can’t even begin to express how fun and exciting it is to get to be a part of the journey as we usher in the largest gameplay update to League ever! We’re super stoked to see how the new system changes how you look at the game, how they impact the decisions you make, and how your path to victory is forged with the new runes. They've been live for 2 full days now (1 if you’re not from OCE), and we're starting to get a clearer picture of what the “balance” landscape looks like in this new world. We’re seeing tons of experimentation (Klepto support GP, Glacial Augment Jhin) which we’re super happy to see, as those creative decisions are something we were really hoping to get out of Runes. With that in mind, I'd like to take a moment to briefly discuss how we'll be approaching balance in the next few days/weeks in this post, and make sure everyone get an idea of what at a high level we're going to try to accomplish over the course of pre-season. This is likely the first of a number of posts over the next while 

Firstly, our goal is not going to be “get every champion to 50% winrate as fast as possible”. That wasn't our goal before pre-season, and that doesn’t change with everything out in the wild now. With Runes we expect to see a lot more creative decision making than before, choices that vary based on the champion you’re taking, your team comp, and who you’re facing. There’s sure to end up being some level of optimization between champions and the new runes system, but when a player gets creative and comes up with a really smart combination of champion and runes, we expect them to also be rewarded with a greater chance to succeed. That being said, there are always edge cases, and if we see something that warps gameplay in a way we’re not happy with we’ll step in and intervene even if winrates look within reason. We're also likely to step in if it appears that some champions are struggling to find success in the new system, as we want you to be able to take any champion, make cool choices, and have a chance to win.

We’re starting to get an idea of how things are shaking out, though for a change so huge it’s going to take quite some time until dust settles and we have a clear picture of how everything looks both as individual pieces, and in the larger picture. We're going to try to solve the right issue, so if we see a champion succeeding disproportionately with a specific set of Runes compared to other champions in it’s class, we’re likely to take a good hard look at that individual champion and the things that changed around it (base stats, keystones etc). If an entire class moves disproportionately, that’s a signal of systemic changes being the culprit, so we’ll look to solve that as opposed to changing each individual champion. We don’t want to make the mistake of over correcting anything (champions/runes/items etc), since preseason is supposed to be a time of experimentation and creative decision making, but you can expect us to start acting proactively on things we’re not quite comfortable with. Tomorrow we’re likely to start talking about what we intend to micropatch and work on before Patch 7.23 lands.

We're super pumped to see the crazy shit you’re trying, so keep it coming and [Preseason responsibly](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1FUrZX54jw8).

We're likely to need to make different systemic changes to allow non adcs to function in the botlane alongside a support. We could very well see some new gameplay options emerge in regards to champions in off roles, but things like objective tuning, income streams, itemization, champion synergies etc that make it hard for players to just take a champion that "could" be viable in another role and then actually take them there. 

If we were to see some pro streamers suddenly start playing things like Camille bot with agro supports like Leona or Alistar - we'd probably see a huge surge in those specific pairing/s crop up in games, but players tend to wait until they see something be successful until they themselves take the risk. Insert "I saw Scara do it on stream" here. :P

I think it'd help if you used the new "Adaptive" mechanic to help AP's in bot lane, but built into kits. EX: Janna shield give however much AD or AP, adaptively, or do neat little things like have Lulu's MS boost (Forgot what it's called) give either Attack Speed or a small amount of AP based on bonus MS for the duration, adaptively.

My knee-jerk reaction ... Not a fan so far ... I play tank heavy champs and feel like I have very very very few pigeon-holed options compared to every other "class" in the game.

As someone who plays bruisers, tanks and juggernauts it seems like RIOT only made sure that ADC and Mages are well represented with options in the new system.

I can barely even raise my resistances for goodness-sakes.  

I'll keep plugging along, but right now ... this feels very lack-luster ... I feel like it will be even worst than last season.  I'll end up making about 3 "run pages" and that will pretty much be it because there are zero options for building tanky champs.

I feel like Guardian is really punishing and awkward. If you're playing the type of champion that wants to use Guardian (a tank, who is more likely to have a larger character model than a squishy character) you practically have to get ontop of your allies to even set up the Guard. The radius is incredibly small. I feel like I'm playing Sona each time I try to use it, and that's not a good thing.

That's some really good feedback dude, I'll pass that along to the folks that worked on it. No idea if there's currently room to change much, but feedback like "I feel like I'm playing Sona each time I try to use it" is quite powerful/telling of the experience. 

Small aside: We're going to be micropatching some buffs to your boy today. Nothing particularly exciting, but he's struggling a bit more in runes than we'd like (not having a super obvious option as a keystone as you pointed out a few weeks ago is certainly a part of it, but that's a bigger problem to solve).

I'm not sure if it's a problem, but I'd use guardian mostly on tanky melee supports, and since I'm melee while the ADC is ranged, I'm closer to the enemy champions than my ADC and thus am often out of range to trigger the shield...

If you're closer to the enemy, then you probably want to use Aftershock because you must be playing something like Leona or Alistar.

If you play Braum, or someone like him, you should definitely be closer to your ADC than the enemy.

Would there be a way to adjust rune effects in general to increase their size based on the overall size of the champion's hit box? At least up to a limit, i wouldn't expect full-size Cho or Zac to get a lane-wide Aftershock of course, but something?

As i understand it, the general idea is to make tankier champs larger, so they're easier to hit with skillshots. In theory, it's to help us bodyblock for teammates, yes? But in practice, being bigger causes me to eat unnecessary damage and CC more often than it gives me that extra size needed to take a Nidalee spear for an ally. The AoE effects of runes being larger on larger champions should be a reasonable trade. Easier to get hit, easier to hit others.

I asked this on Meddler's post but I think it might fit better here:

Has there been any discussion about changing the UI for selecting Runes in Champ Select to feel more like "select your runes for this game" as opposed to "select one of your rune pages (and possibly edit your pages in the process)"? The high price of pages feels super limiting when you have to actually modify one of those pages every time you're customizing runes for a particular game, and it puts a barrier in front of experimentation: "I'd like to use the preset Precision page but tweak it slightly" should be easy, but it really isn't if you've only got the default two pages and you're already using them both.
It is nice to hear general principles but when will we hear actual specifics on balance?

If by specifics you mean specific champions you'll hear more tomorrow in Meddler's Quick Gameplay thoughts. Then we're likely to talk a bit more openly going forward as we get further into pre-season.
Yes, thank you

Quick question.

Which runes do you see as being over-the-top and which ones are underwhelming, from initial observations?

I won't take this as a promise as to what will be nerfed and what won't, but I'm curious what  it looks like through your eyes.

I should have replied earlier, but opted for Meddler's post today. Right now we're seeing Aftershock, Guardian and Aery are all seeming a bit on the strong side, so we're going to be keeping a close eye and see what we need to do (potentially some stuff in 7.23). On the underwhelming side it's a bit harder to say given the number of other factors up in the air. Predator is one that's probably not as strong as it should be, but there's so much going on that it's not quite clear yet.

I love how much more carry potential the dmg dealers have again. Even if snowballing might be too insane atm, (we'll have to see) I love that as a mid-lane burst mage player I feel like I can impact the actual game again. 

Tank meta made my champion pool scream. Ahri, Lux, and other burst mages feel so much better with this system. Since everyone is squishier though it means as a damage dealer you die pretty fast so it definitely feels fair so far in my experience. 
 
Snowballing does seem to feel a little off, teams are stomping pretty hard but I think it might just a case of people who are playing with optimal choices of runes vs. those that just chose randomly, or what they were told was op ((but not understanding why, or how)).

But with no straight up base stat runes to fall back on, getting behind is rough. Maybe the advantages of getting an early lead will just need reduced. I noticed that herald  feels really strong right now.

So I just had a thought. I know the whole 'Adaptive' thing has been a big part of the new runes, and I think it was a good and creative way to give both AD and AP champs access to a lot of the runes. But what if you took it a step further and were willing to include other stats? Say you have a really versatile fighter champ with a rune that granted AD or AR, adaptive. this could allow them to be more versatile in building more as a tank, or as a duelist. Especially considering a lot of the concerns with the removal of flat stats that the old system granted, you could even potentially do this with more rune bonuses, like sorcery has done with its AP/AD bonus for choosing it as your primary. Could something like that work?

I’m mostly enjoying my time with runes, but I will agree that the resolve tree is far more lackluster than I was hoping. Outside of the keystones, your decisions don’t seem particularly impactful, nor do they seem particularly diverse.

As an example, other than the one rune in sorcery, I see no runes that offer temporary shields outside of Guardian, which is honestly made for supports. While I get that shield stacking was a problem last season, having active survivability tools in the top lane in runes might help make full tank picks more appealing.
